reviewText: These are excellent performances, but they are electric with very fast allegro movements.  Not all listeners will respond well to them:  fans of Furtwangler, Bohm, and Bruno Walter in these symphonies may not like Kleiber, considering him too glib, and that he misses/glosses over important points.  But the precision of the Concertgebouw Orchestra players is thrilling!Sound quality and picture quality are both excellent.  DVD picture is full screen, and has great perspectives/shots of Kleiber in dramatic moments or of a flute, clarinet, oboe, etc. player when they have a solo lick/passage.The Concertgebouw Orchestra plays better for Kleiber in Symphony 4 here than the Bavarian State Orchestra (also a live recording) did in 1982 (Orfeo CD).  Kleiber's 7th here is superior to his Vienna Philharmonic studio recording from 1976(DG CD): I and IV sparkle more here.  The intensity and excitement of playing in front of a live audience helps.  The audience clearly loved Kleiber, and it shows.
summary: Electric performances with very fast allegros from 1983
Title: N/A

reviewText: There is little with which to find fault in Kleiber's approach to Beethoven's symphonic output. The performances on this DVD are crisp, competent, approaching flawlessness. Yet for me, they are far from definitive. The 4th symphony does not make great demands upon the conductor. The present interpretation is as good as you will get, which is to say that it matches the level of about half-a-dozen others available in recorded form, including DVDs by Karajan and Abbado. The 7th is a different matter. It is fiendishly difficult to preserve the texture of the last two movements and simultaneously keep up the break-neck pace that Beethoven demands. Too easily, it can degenerate into a jolly rumpty-tum romp on the village green that reduces the stature of the music from patrician, as it should be, to plebeian as it too often becomes. Regrettably, there are moments during this performance when Kleiber allows this to occur. One has to add that the Concertgebouw Orchestra, distinguished though it is, has not won the reputation enjoyed by the BPO and the VPO in the realm of Beethoven Symphonies, and there is only so much than even the most gifted conductor can do in these circumstances. The Camera work is top notch, and paradoxically displays the light-hearted approach that Kleiber brings to this majestic music, illustrating the complaint of superficiality I have just enunciated. Nothing wrong with the sound, either, although Surround did not work as well as Dolby Stereo on my system. All in all, a worthwhile buy, but not deserving of 5 stars.
summary: Very good but not truly great
Title: N/A

reviewText: With the death of Carlos Kliber, there is a huge void left in the world of classical music. It is sad that he has left behind so few of his recorded works and the present set of DVDs enables all of us to see the passion with which he conducted music. The present set gives us superlative performances of both the 4th and the 7th- performances that will be treasured by all music lovers for a life time.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a very long waited DVD by all those who knew the Laser Disc with this same performances filmed live in the Dutch Concertgebouw in the `80s.First of all we have to mention the very close relation that exist between Carlos Kleiber and Beethoven's world, specially with the Seventh Symphony he have conducted lot of times. We knew his audio recording with the Wiener Philharmoniker for Deutsche Grammophon, one of the most interesting I know, but not really so good like this, much more fresh and well done. Of course, the Wiener is an orchestra I like a little more than the Concertgebouworkest, but the Dutch one is good enough to play a fantastic concert like this, in which is easy to see everything was deeply rehearsed and prepared before going to the stage. Sometimes Kleiber even is `dancing' with the orchestra and enjoining the results of all the previous work. The tempi are fresh and light, pure Kleiber style and the sound is, like everybody use to describe, `electrifying', very passionate. Wagner said this Beethoven's Seventh is the `apotheosis of the dance' and we can say Kleiber really does it, dancing even himself with his body and swinging his baton. Probably my favourite Seventh together with very good one of Szell & Cleveland (Sony).Sound is quite good, not excellent but good enough to be an `80s recording by Philips. You will need to rise the volume quite high but the clearness, balance and definition is good. The image is very good to, joining shots of Kleiber, the orchestra and the Concertgebouw hall, a really fantastic place in which public, enthusiastic, embrace the orchestra.The orchestra is the smooth and very technical Concertgebouworkest, not always very fine in Beethoven (perfect in Mahler and other repertoires, even form the XXth Century Music), but with a great day here, what a woodwinds!The Fourth is quite good too, but not so great like the Seventh. In this Fourth Symphony I really prefer Bernstein's performance with the Wiener Philharmoniker (DG).If I'm realistic, the media of the performances would be 4 and some decimals, but as we are watching a wonderful piece of history and listening a wonderful player, it will be five.Highly recommended.
Title: N/A

reviewText: XXXXXLudwig van Beethoven (1770 to 1827) created nine symphonies that are spiritual dramas of universal appeal.  In this DVD, two of them (composed before he was completely deaf) are performed by an orchestra led by "one of the most remarkable conductors of the twentieth century"--Carlos Kleiber (1930 to 2004), son of the late, great Austrian conductor Erich Kleiber.The first symphony performed is Symphony #4 in B flat major, opus 60.  The score was written in 1806.  It is characterized by it "deceptive lightness."  Tempo of its movements is as follows:(1) Adagio - Allegro vivace(2) Adagio(3) Allegro vivace(4) Allegro ma non troppoThe second symphony is Symphony #7 in A major, opus 92.  Its score was written in 1811-12.  This symphony is "ruled by rhythm."  For me, the Seventh seems to rival Beethoven's Fifth in its universal appeal.  It has four movements with the following tempos:(1) Poco sostenuto--Vivace(2) Allegretto(3) Presto--Assai meno presto(4) Allegro con brioEach symphony is about 34 minutes long.Filming was live at the Concertgebouw, Amsterdam.I could see why Kleiber received such high accolades as a conductor.  He led the Cocertgebouw Orchestra with great passion and dynamic flare resulting in two unforgettable performances.Finally, the DVD itself (the one released in 2005) is perfect in sound and picture quality.In conclusion, this is a chance to see a great composer in action as he gives us his interpretation of two great symphonies!!(1983;  70 min;  full screen)<<Stephen Pletko, London, Ontario, Canada>>XXXXX
summary: Two Beethoven symphonies led by "the conductor who could not tolerate error"
